events.title: Roger Bannister breaks the four-minute mile
events.description: British athlete Roger Bannister becomes the first person to run a mile in under four minutes, clocking 3 minutes 59.4 seconds.
events.significance: Marked a significant achievement in athletics, breaking a psychological and physical barrier that had been considered impossible for decades.

events.title: The Hindenburg disaster
events.description: The German passenger airship LZ 129 Hindenburg catches fire and is destroyed during its attempt to dock at Lakehurst Naval Air Station in New Jersey.
events.significance: This tragic event marked the end of the airship era and had a lasting impact on public confidence in airship travel.

events.title: Sack of Rome
events.description: Troops of Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, sack Rome, marking the end of the Italian Renaissance.
events.significance: This event shifted the political landscape of Italy and Europe, weakening the power of the Papacy and marking a turning point in Renaissance history.

events.title: Elections in South Africa end apartheid
events.description: South Africa holds its first post-apartheid general elections, allowing citizens of all races to vote for the first time.
events.significance: Marked the official end of apartheid and led to Nelson Mandela becoming South Africa's first black president, a pivotal moment in world history.

events.title: First performance of Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. 4
events.description: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky’s Fourth Symphony is premiered in Moscow, conducted by Nikolai Rubinstein.
events.significance: This work is regarded as one of Tchaikovsky's most important symphonies, displaying his emotional depth and contributing significantly to classical music.
